readings.title: Uncertainty in Parenting
readings.original:
Parenting can feel like walking in the dark. There are many books and experts offering advice, but each child is different. What works for one family may not work for another. Parents often feel unsure, even when trying their best.

In daily life, parents deal with real-time problems like calming a crying baby or solving school issues. There is no perfect manual. Parents learn as they go, making mistakes and growing with their children. That’s why parenting is often called the hardest job in the world.
readings.simplified:
Parenting is not easy. Many books give advice, but each child is different. Parents often do not know what to do.

In real life, parents must help children right away. There is no perfect guide. Parents learn by doing and make mistakes. They grow with their children.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: There are many perfect books on parenting.
Parents never know what they are doing.
Parenting is full of uncertainty and learning.
All children are the same.
questions.answer: Parenting is full of uncertainty and learning.
questions.hint: Focus on what the passage says about learning through parenting.

questions.question: What does 'real-time problems' most likely mean in the passage?
options: Problems that happen during a TV show.
Problems that need quick action in daily life.
Problems that experts solve in books.
Problems that are not real.
questions.answer: Problems that need quick action in daily life.
questions.hint: Look at how parents must respond immediately.

questions.question: True or False: The passage says every child is the same.
What does 'Parenting can feel like walking in the dark' mean?
options: It is usually done at night.
Parents know exactly what to do.
It can be confusing and uncertain.
It is about going outside with children.
questions.answer: It can be confusing and uncertain.
questions.hint: Think about what it means to walk in the dark.

questions.question: Why is there no perfect manual for parenting?
options: Because books are not sold anymore.
Because parenting is easy.
Because each family and child is different.
Because no one wants a guide.
questions.answer: Because each family and child is different.
questions.hint: Focus on the variety mentioned in the first paragraph.

readings.howToUse: Use this passage to explore how uncertainty affects parenting. Discuss different experiences of parents and how they learn through real situations.

readings.title: The Meaning of Knowing People
readings.original:
In the past, knowing someone meant seeing them often. You knew their face, voice, and how they acted. You talked to them in person, shared meals, and saw how they treated others. Friendship and trust grew through time spent together.

Today, we often 'know' people online. We read their posts, see pictures, and send messages. But we don’t know their faces, their voices, or even if they are real. The way we connect has changed. We must think about what it really means to know someone.
readings.simplified:
Before, knowing someone meant seeing their face and talking with them often. You spent time together in real life.

Now, we often meet people online. We see pictures and messages, but we don’t know their face or voice. We should think about what 'knowing someone' really means.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: People do not eat together anymore.
We know people better now than before.
Knowing people has not changed.
The way we know people has changed.
questions.answer: The way we know people has changed.
questions.hint: Look at how the past and present are compared.

questions.question: What does 'connect' most likely mean in the second paragraph?
options: To build something with tools.
To meet and feel close to people.
To fix something broken.
To run quickly.
questions.answer: To meet and feel close to people.
questions.hint: Think about how we ‘connect’ with others.

questions.question: True or False: The passage says we always know people’s real faces online.
What does “We don’t know their faces, their voices, or even if they are real.” mean?
options: We know people too well.
Everyone online uses fake names and voices.
We often don’t know the physical appearance or real identity of people online.
People online are always real friends.
questions.answer: We often don’t know the physical appearance or real identity of people online.
questions.hint: The sentence says what is missing in online contact.

questions.question: Does the passage say the modern way of knowing people is good or bad?
options: Good
Bad
Both good and bad
The author does not say clearly
questions.answer: The author does not say clearly
questions.hint: Think about whether the writer gives a judgment.

glossary.definition: to join or feel close to someone

readings.howToUse: Use this passage to talk about how relationships have changed in the digital world. Ask students how they define 'knowing' someone today.
